titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck, September 8, 1906
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
titleStmt.sponsor: Supported in part by a grant from the Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund, a program of the Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources.

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck

msIdentifier.repository: University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center, Buffalo Bill: Letters to George T. Beck, 1895-1910 (Acc. #9972)

div1.p: Your letter came to day And as Geo. B. Harris2 is so anxious to know what the people of Cody & my self are doing about the high line canal— I took the liberty of sending him your letter.

Well George— YestardayYesterday Mr Geo. O. Starr3 Presedent of the Barnum & Bailey Ltd. Co. came over from America to see me— About showing in America. And I signed the best show contract for Little Willie4 that he has ever had— And the first good one I have ever had. Mr Starr left soon as the contract was signed for America to commence building an entire new outfit for me— 60 new cars— &c. I got L5 in Hungary & Poland but have puledpulled out in Germany.
IllI'll tell you all about it in the Rockies when we make our ten days hunt

closer.salute: Love to family. Kiss Betty6 for me

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed at Monchengladbach, Germany, on September 8, 1906. Cody abbreviates the German city as "Gladback."
Note 2: George B. Harris (1866-1918), second vice-president of the C. B. & Q. Railroad, became president of the company in 1901 until his resignation in 1910.

Note 3: George O. Starr (1849-1915) began his show career in a dime museum in the Bowery, becoming the press agent for P. T. Barnum's circus in 1878; by 1905 he was general manager for Barnum & Bailey.
Note 4: "Little Willie" is Cody's reference to himself.
Note 6: "Betty" refers to George Beck's daughter who was born in Cody, Wyoming, in 1898.
